Mar 10

Could UX Designers benefit board games?

If you haven’t heard, board games these days are becoming a pretty big deal. They are continuously pushing the limits of what we once thought a board game could be all the while growing in popularity around the globe. Part of that popularity can be attributed to the ever more present rigorous design and play testing process in the development of these games. In simple sense a lot of these game designers are acting as inexperienced UX designers as they continuously polish their games. But in a lot of ways the UX of most games falls short.

But what if UX design professionals became fully involved in a board games’ development process?

Here is an example of a game that in the board game community is heralded as one of the best examples of a game with great UI. The game is Scythe by Jamey Stegmaier.

Now, Scythe is a great game and you can tell that a lot of time and consideration was involved in the design process but as beautiful and intuitive the game is I feel that a UX designer could have taken it to the next level.

I’m not going to go into a whole analysis on all the ways a UX designer would change about the game but I will talk about one example to give some sort of merit that UX belongs in game design.

To the player boards!

Let me first state that there is a lot going right with these player boards. The recessed cut outs make an otherwise intimidating setup process a breeze and the icons are well thought out and easy to understand. But there is one main thing wrong with these boards that a seasoned UX designer would instantly spot; the lack of hierarchy.

Not to go into to much detail on how to play the game but the four sections on the board indicate different actions you may take during your turn. The problem though is that the action for each section isn’t clearly labeled. It’s hidden below the pay line at the top of the board. It should say move, trade, produce and bolster boldly at the tops of each section for easy identification.

Is this a detail that ruins the game? Of course not, but it’s a simple and fixable thing that would make the game a bit easier to learn.

In this ultra competitive market where good games are being produced all the time, I feel having a UX designer working along the sides of the game designer, graphic designer and illustrator is going to be the way to push a good game into a great game.

Let me hear your thoughts in the comments.
